headline: American children can’t be pawns in Trump immigration war | Opinion | Miami Herald
context: Somebody please explain to me why a mother of a nursing baby, whose husband is a U.S. citizen, was snatched from her family and sent back to Cuba.

Or why a mother and her 4-year-old son with Stage 4 metastatic cancer — a U.S. citizen — were sent to Honduras, where the child most likely won’t get the treatment that could possibly save his life. (Trump administration officials said the undocumented mother chose to bring her son with her as she was deported.)

annotations.paragraph: Why is this happening in our America, that once invited “... your huddled masses yearning to breathe free” to come here?

annotations.paragraph: Something is wrong. I understand that in the case of Kilmar Armando Abrego Garcia, the Maryland man who was unlawfully deported by the Trump administration in March to the horrific prison in El Salvador — there was the question of him being a gang member. Yet Abrego Garcia has never been charged with or convicted of being a member of MS-13.

annotations.paragraph: These deportation antics remind me of the children who were separated from their immigrant parents during Trump’s first run as president. It was so sad to see how Trump officials handled the migrants back then, taking tiny babies from their mothers and placing small children in shelters that resembled cages.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context and comparison to past events related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: As a mother, grandmother and great-grandmother, those scenes still tug at my heart. I cannot imagine being separated from my babies in such a cruel way. Like many of you, I feel helpless because I don’t know what to do. So, I pray often for these children and their parents.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is personal reflection and does not add new information to the article.

annotations.paragraph: While it was bad back then, it’s worse now, where people are being picked up and sent back almost immediately, without so much as a goodbye to their loved ones, who in some cases are U.S. citizens. In Sánchez’s case, according to the Herald story by Nora Gámez Torres, she was sent back to Cuba last Thursday morning, after being detained by Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials at her check-in appointment in Tampa on Tuesday of that week. She was one of 82 people returned to Cuba.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about recent deportations, directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: There are illegal immigrants living here who are criminals. Sanchez is not one of them. She is just a woman who found love with an American citizen, had a child and was living her dream.

annotations.paragraph: The criminals who have come to this country should be departed. But that isn’t always the case. Tell me — how will this country benefit by deporting nursing mothers? How will it benefit the children and the spouses who are citizens who are left behind?

annotations.paragraph: Deportation is not pretty. But I understand it is sometimes a necessary evil. Still, I believe that more thought should be given to who should and who should not be departed. American children are being departed along with their undocumented mothers/parents. We need to fix this.
